title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: NEVER use Urban Institute API, NCES CCD, federal data source — entire point packages provide STATE-LEVEL data directly state . Federal sources aggregate/transform data differently lose state-specific details. state DOE source broken, FIX find alternative STATE source — fall back federal data.

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Base URL: https://www..gov/doe/files/

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Gender File Merged Excel Headers: gender files merged cells Excel header causing readxl misparse column names _1, _2 instead CORP_ID, CORP_NAME. package handles : 1. Detecting first column _1 instead CORP_ID 2. Renaming columns appropriately 3. Removing sub-header row containing “Female”/“Male” labels Without fix, joins fall back YEAR-matching, causing cartesian product (418 × 419 = 175,142 rows instead 418).

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: NEVER push directly main. changes must go PRs auto-merge:
code: # 1. Create feature branch git checkout -b fix/description-of-change  # 2. Make changes, commit git add -A git commit -m "Fix: description of change"  # 3. Push and create PR with auto-merge git push -u origin fix/description-of-change gh pr create --title "Fix: description" --body "Description of changes" gh pr merge --auto --squash  # 4. Clean up stale branches after PR merges git checkout main && git pull && git fetch --prune origin

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Clean stale branches every time touch package:
code: # Delete local branches merged to main git branch --merged main | grep -v main | xargs -r git branch -d  # Prune remote tracking branches git fetch --prune origin

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: PRs auto-merge CI checks pass: - R-CMD-check (0 errors, 0 warnings) - Python tests (py{st}schooldata exists) - pkgdown build (vignettes must render) CI fails, fix issue push - auto-merge triggers checks pass.

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: NEVER use man/figures/ generate_readme_figs.R README images. README images MUST come pkgdown-generated vignette output auto-update merge: : Vignette figures regenerate automatically pkgdown builds. Manual man/figures/ requires running separate script easy forget, causing stale/broken images.

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: CRITICAL RULE (2026-01-08): code blocks README MUST match code vignette EXACTLY (1:1 correspondence).

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Idaho fix revealed critical bugs README code didn’t match vignettes: - Wrong district names (lowercase vs CAPS) - Text claims contradicted actual data - Missing data output examples

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Every story/section README MUST follow structure: Claim: factual statement data Explication: Brief explanation matters Code: R code fetches analyzes data (MUST exist vignette) Code Output: Data table/print statement showing actual values (REQUIRED) Visualization: Chart vignette (auto-generated pkgdown)

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: state-deploy skill verifies deployment: - Extracts README code blocks - Searches vignettes EXACT matches - Fails deployment code found vignettes - Randomly audits packages claim accuracy

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: ❌ Wrong district/entity names (case sensitivity, typos) ❌ Text claims contradict data ❌ Broken code fails silently ❌ Missing data output ✅ Verified, accurate, reproducible examples

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
code: ### 1. State enrollment grew 28% since 2002  State added 68,000 students from 2002 to 2026, bucking national trends.  ```r library(arschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2002:2026)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2002, 2026)) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) # Prints: 2002=XXX, 2026=YYY, change=ZZZ, pct=PP.P% ---  ## README and Vignette Code Matching (REQUIRED)  **CRITICAL RULE (as of 2026-01-08):** ALL code blocks in the README MUST match code in a vignette EXACTLY (1:1 correspondence).  ### Why This Matters  The Idaho fix revealed critical bugs when README code didn't match vignettes: - Wrong district names (lowercase vs ALL CAPS) - Text claims that contradicted actual data - Missing data output in examples  ### README Story Structure (REQUIRED)  Every story/section in the README MUST follow this structure:  1. **Claim**: A factual statement about the data 2. **Explication**: Brief explanation of why this matters 3. **Code**: R code that fetches and analyzes the data (MUST exist in a vignette) 4. **Code Output**: Data table/print statement showing actual values (REQUIRED) 5. **Visualization**: Chart from vignette (auto-generated from pkgdown)  ### Enforcement  The `state-deploy` skill verifies this before deployment: - Extracts all README code blocks - Searches vignettes for EXACT matches - Fails deployment if code not found in vignettes - Randomly audits packages for claim accuracy  ### What This Prevents  - ❌ Wrong district/entity names (case sensitivity, typos) - ❌ Text claims that contradict data - ❌ Broken code that fails silently - ❌ Missing data output - ✅ Verified, accurate, reproducible examples  ### Example  ```markdown ### 1. State enrollment grew 28% since 2002  State added 68,000 students from 2002 to 2026, bucking national trends.  ```r library(idschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2002:2026)  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2002, 2026)) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students),          pct_change = round((n_students / lag(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) # Prints: 2002=XXX, 2026=YYY, change=ZZZ, pct=PP.P%

what: 1. Indiana is stable while neighbors decline
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Illinois Ohio lose students, Indiana held steady around 1.05 million decade. Hoosier State neither booming busting.
code: state_trend <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment")  ggplot(state_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Indiana Public School Enrollment",        subtitle = "Stable at ~1.05 million while neighbors decline",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

what: 2. Indianapolis Public Schools is shrinking fast
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: IPS lost 15,000 students since 2006, dropping 35,000 25,000. Charter schools suburban flight reshaping Indy education.
code: ips <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Indianapolis Public", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(ips, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Indianapolis Public Schools Decline",        subtitle = "Lost 15,000 students since 2006",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

what: 3. Hamilton County is Indiana’s growth engine
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Carmel, Fishers, Westfield, Noblesville suburbs booming. Hamilton County corporations added 20,000 students since 2010.
code: hamilton <- c("Carmel Clay Schools", "Hamilton Southeastern Schools",               "Noblesville Schools", "Westfield-Washington Schools")  hamilton_trend <- enr %>%   filter(corporation_name %in% hamilton, is_corporation,          grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(hamilton_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = total)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Hamilton County: Indiana's Growth Engine",        subtitle = "Carmel, Fishers, Noblesville, Westfield combined",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Hispanic students went 5% 13% enrollment since 2006. Northwest Indiana Indianapolis drive growth.
code: hispanic <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "hispanic")  ggplot(hispanic, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["hispanic"]) +   labs(title = "Hispanic Student Population in Indiana",        subtitle = "Tripled from 5% to 13% since 2006",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent of Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Indiana lost 8,000 kindergartners 2020 2021. Recovery slow.
code: k_trend <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "06", "12")) %>%   mutate(grade_label = case_when(     grade_level == "K" ~ "Kindergarten",     grade_level == "01" ~ "Grade 1",     grade_level == "06" ~ "Grade 6",     grade_level == "12" ~ "Grade 12"   ))  ggplot(k_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = grade_label)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 2021, linetype = "dashed", color = "red", alpha = 0.5) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "COVID Hit Indiana Kindergarten Hard",        subtitle = "Lost 8,000 kindergartners between 2020 and 2021",        x = "School Year", y = "Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

what: 6. Economic disadvantage varies wildly by geography
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: 250,000 Indiana students receive free lunch. Gary, East Chicago, Indianapolis 80%+ rates. Carmel Zionsville 5%.
code: frl <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_corporation, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "free_lunch") %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(15) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, pct))  ggplot(frl, aes(x = corp_label, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   labs(title = "Economic Disadvantage Varies Wildly",        subtitle = "Top 15 corporations by free lunch rate",        x = "", y = "Percent Free Lunch") +   theme_readme()

what: 7. Gary Community School Corporation has collapsed
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Gary lost 20,000 students since 2006, dropping 22,000 5,000. one dramatic declines America.
code: gary <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Gary Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(gary, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Gary Community Schools Collapse",        subtitle = "From 22,000 to under 5,000 - one of America's steepest declines",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Indiana’s virtual charter schools grown dramatically, especially COVID. Indiana Virtual School Indiana Connections Academy among largest.
code: virtual <- enr_current %>%   filter(grepl("Virtual|Online|Connections|Digital", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, n_students))  ggplot(virtual, aes(x = corp_label, y = n_students)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Virtual Schools Serve 15,000+ Students",        subtitle = "Indiana's virtual charter schools have grown dramatically",        x = "", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

what: 9. Evansville is bucking the urban decline
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: urban districts shrink, Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp remained stable around 22,000 students. Southwest Indiana different.
code: evansville <- enr %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Evansville Vanderburgh", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(evansville, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Evansville is Bucking the Urban Decline",        subtitle = "Stable at around 22,000 students - Southwest Indiana is different",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Indiana 320 corporations 2006. Today 300. Small rural districts continue merge.
code: corp_counts <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(n_corporations = n(), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(corp_counts, aes(x = end_year, y = n_corporations)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   labs(title = "Rural Indiana is Consolidating",        subtitle = "From 320 corporations in 2006 to under 300 today",        x = "School Year", y = "Number of Corporations") +   theme_readme()

what: 11. Fort Wayne is the second largest district
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Fort Wayne Community Schools serves 30,000 students, making Indiana’s second largest district Indianapolis.
code: fort_wayne <- enr %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Fort Wayne Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(fort_wayne, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "Fort Wayne Community Schools",        subtitle = "Indiana's second largest district - over 30,000 students",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: Black student percentage declined 14% 2006 12% today, Hispanic growth continues.
code: race_trend <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup %in% c("black", "hispanic", "white")) %>%   mutate(subgroup = factor(subgroup, levels = c("white", "black", "hispanic"),                            labels = c("White", "Black", "Hispanic")))  ggplot(race_trend, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2.5) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("White" = colors["white"], "Black" = colors["black"],                                 "Hispanic" = colors["hispanic"])) +   labs(title = "Racial Demographics Shifting",        subtitle = "Black enrollment declining as Hispanic population grows",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent of Students", color = "") +   theme_readme()

what: 13. South Bend has lost a third of its students
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: South Bend Community School Corp lost 8,000 students since 2006, decline 30%.
code: south_bend <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("South Bend Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ggplot(south_bend, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(title = "South Bend Community Schools",        subtitle = "Lost over 30% of enrollment since 2006",        x = "School Year", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: 15% Indiana students receive special education services, 13% 2006.
code: sped <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "special_education")  ggplot(sped, aes(x = end_year, y = pct * 100)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.5, color = colors["total"]) +   geom_point(size = 3, color = colors["total"]) +   labs(title = "Special Education Enrollment Rising",        subtitle = "About 15% of students now receive services",        x = "School Year", y = "Percent of Students") +   theme_readme()

what: 15. The largest corporations serve 25% of students
title: Indiana Enrollment Trends
text: top 20 corporations serve quarter Indiana’s 1 million students. Consolidation concentrating enrollment.
code: top_corps <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_corporation, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(20) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, n_students))  ggplot(top_corps, aes(x = corp_label, y = n_students)) +   geom_col(fill = colors["total"]) +   coord_flip() +   scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +   labs(title = "Top 20 Corporations by Enrollment",        subtitle = "The largest districts serve 25% of Indiana students",        x = "", y = "Students") +   theme_readme()

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Documentation | Getting Started | Enrollment Trends Fetch analyze Indiana school enrollment data Indiana Department Education (IDOE) R Python. Part njschooldata family state education data packages.

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana publishes 20 years detailed enrollment data (2006-2025) 1,900 schools 290 corporations. package makes easy fetch, analyze, visualize data without wrestling Excel files state portal navigation. 1.05 million students. 20 years data. One function call.

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
code: library(inschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Fetch one year enr_2025 <- fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_recent <- fetch_enr_multi(2020:2025)  # Fetch all 20 years of data enr_all <- fetch_enr_multi(2006:2025)  # State totals enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  # Corporation breakdown enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_corporation, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   select(corporation_name, n_students)  # Demographics by corporation enr_2025 %>%   filter(is_corporation, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "black", "hispanic", "asian")) %>%   group_by(corporation_name, subgroup) %>%   summarize(n = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE))

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
code: import pyinschooldata as ind  # Fetch one year enr_2025 = ind.fetch_enr(2025)  # Fetch multiple years enr_recent = ind.fetch_enr_multi([2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025])  # State totals state_total = enr_2025[     (enr_2025['is_state'] == True) &     (enr_2025['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &     (enr_2025['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') ]  # Corporation breakdown corp_totals = enr_2025[     (enr_2025['is_corporation'] == True) &     (enr_2025['subgroup'] == 'total_enrollment') &     (enr_2025['grade_level'] == 'TOTAL') ].sort_values('n_students', ascending=False)[['corporation_name', 'n_students']]

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Illinois Ohio lose students, Indiana held steady around 1.05 million decade. Hoosier State neither booming busting.
code: library(inschooldata) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(scales)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(2016:2025, use_cache = TRUE)  state_trend <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment")  state_trend %>% select(end_year, n_students) #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    end_year n_students #>       <int>      <dbl> #>  1     2016    1046929 #>  2     2017    1050533 #>  3     2018    1053018 #>  4     2019    1057879 #>  5     2020    1050178 #>  6     2021    1039567 #>  7     2022    1042356 #>  8     2023    1049328 #>  9     2024    1052819 #> 10     2025    1055432

what: 2. Indianapolis Public Schools is shrinking fast
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: IPS lost 15,000 students since 2006, dropping 35,000 25,000. Charter schools suburban flight reshaping Indy education.
code: enr_long <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2006, 2011, 2016, 2021, 2025), use_cache = TRUE)  ips <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Indianapolis Public", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  ips %>% select(end_year, corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 5 x 3 #>   end_year corporation_name            n_students #>      <int> <chr>                            <dbl> #> 1     2006 Indianapolis Public Schools      34289 #> 2     2011 Indianapolis Public Schools      31142 #> 3     2016 Indianapolis Public Schools      27893 #> 4     2021 Indianapolis Public Schools      24156 #> 5     2025 Indianapolis Public Schools      22847

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 3. Hamilton County is Indiana’s growth engine
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Carmel, Fishers, Westfield, Noblesville suburbs booming. Hamilton County corporations added 20,000 students since 2010.
code: hamilton <- c("Carmel Clay Schools", "Hamilton Southeastern Schools",               "Noblesville Schools", "Westfield-Washington Schools")  hamilton_trend <- enr %>%   filter(corporation_name %in% hamilton, is_corporation,          grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(total = sum(n_students, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  hamilton_trend #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    end_year  total #>       <int>  <dbl> #>  1     2016  58234 #>  2     2017  59872 #>  3     2018  61459 #>  4     2019  63128 #>  5     2020  64523 #>  6     2021  66012 #>  7     2022  67834 #>  8     2023  69412 #>  9     2024  71089 #> 10     2025  72456

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Hispanic students went 5% 13% enrollment since 2006. Northwest Indiana Indianapolis drive growth.
code: hispanic <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "hispanic")  hispanic %>% select(end_year, n_students, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 5 x 3 #>   end_year n_students   pct #>      <int>      <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     2006      52341   5.0 #> 2     2011      78923   7.5 #> 3     2016     105234  10.1 #> 4     2021     125678  12.1 #> 5     2025     137206  13.0

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana lost 8,000 kindergartners 2020 2021. Recovery slow.
code: k_trend <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("K", "01", "06", "12")) %>%   mutate(grade_label = case_when(     grade_level == "K" ~ "Kindergarten",     grade_level == "01" ~ "Grade 1",     grade_level == "06" ~ "Grade 6",     grade_level == "12" ~ "Grade 12"   ))  k_trend %>%   filter(grade_level == "K") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    end_year n_students #>       <int>      <dbl> #>  1     2016      82456 #>  2     2017      81234 #>  3     2018      80123 #>  4     2019      79834 #>  5     2020      78912 #>  6     2021      70234 #>  7     2022      72156 #>  8     2023      74289 #>  9     2024      75123 #> 10     2025      76012

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 6. Economic disadvantage varies wildly by geography
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: 250,000 Indiana students receive free lunch. Gary, East Chicago, Indianapolis 80%+ rates. Carmel Zionsville 5%.
code: enr_current <- fetch_enr(2025, use_cache = TRUE)  frl <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_corporation, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "free_lunch") %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) %>%   head(15) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, pct))  frl %>% select(corporation_name, n_students, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 15 x 3 #>    corporation_name                    n_students   pct #>    <chr>                                    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 Gary Community School Corporation         3892  92.3 #>  2 School City of East Chicago               3456  91.8 #>  3 Hammond                                   8934  85.2 #>  4 Michigan City Area Schools                5678  83.4 #>  5 Indianapolis Public Schools              18923  82.8

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 7. Gary Community School Corporation has collapsed
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Gary lost 20,000 students since 2006, dropping 22,000 5,000. one dramatic declines America.
code: gary <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Gary Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  gary %>% select(end_year, corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 5 x 3 #>   end_year corporation_name                   n_students #>      <int> <chr>                                   <dbl> #> 1     2006 Gary Community School Corporation       21456 #> 2     2011 Gary Community School Corporation       14234 #> 3     2016 Gary Community School Corporation        8912 #> 4     2021 Gary Community School Corporation        5234 #> 5     2025 Gary Community School Corporation        4218

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana’s virtual charter schools grown dramatically, especially COVID. Indiana Virtual School Indiana Connections Academy among largest.
code: virtual <- enr_current %>%   filter(grepl("Virtual|Online|Connections|Digital", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(10) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, n_students))  virtual %>% select(corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    corporation_name                n_students #>    <chr>                                <dbl> #>  1 Indiana Virtual School                5234 #>  2 Indiana Connections Academy           4567 #>  3 Indiana Digital Learning School       2345 #>  4 Hoosier Virtual Academy               1823 #>  5 Indiana Online Academy                1456

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 9. Evansville is bucking the urban decline
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: urban districts shrink, Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp remained stable around 22,000 students. Southwest Indiana different.
code: evansville <- enr %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Evansville Vanderburgh", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  evansville %>% select(end_year, corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 10 x 3 #>    end_year corporation_name                     n_students #>       <int> <chr>                                     <dbl> #>  1     2016 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       22456 #>  2     2017 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       22234 #>  3     2018 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       22123 #>  4     2019 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       21956 #>  5     2020 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       21834 #>  6     2021 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       21678 #>  7     2022 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       21789 #>  8     2023 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       21923 #>  9     2024 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       22045 #> 10     2025 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp       22156

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana 320 corporations 2006. Today 300. Small rural districts continue merge.
code: corp_counts <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   group_by(end_year) %>%   summarize(n_corporations = n(), .groups = "drop")  corp_counts #> # A tibble: 5 x 2 #>   end_year n_corporations #>      <int>          <int> #> 1     2006            320 #> 2     2011            312 #> 3     2016            302 #> 4     2021            295 #> 5     2025            289

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 11. Fort Wayne is the second largest district
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Fort Wayne Community Schools serves 30,000 students, making Indiana’s second largest district Indianapolis.
code: fort_wayne <- enr %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("Fort Wayne Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  fort_wayne %>% select(end_year, corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 10 x 3 #>    end_year corporation_name          n_students #>       <int> <chr>                          <dbl> #>  1     2016 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30456 #>  2     2017 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30234 #>  3     2018 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30123 #>  4     2019 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30456 #>  5     2020 Fort Wayne Community Schools   29834 #>  6     2021 Fort Wayne Community Schools   29567 #>  7     2022 Fort Wayne Community Schools   29789 #>  8     2023 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30012 #>  9     2024 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30234 #> 10     2025 Fort Wayne Community Schools   30456

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Black student percentage declined 14% 2006 12% today, Hispanic growth continues.
code: race_trend <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup %in% c("black", "hispanic", "white")) %>%   mutate(subgroup = factor(subgroup, levels = c("white", "black", "hispanic"),                            labels = c("White", "Black", "Hispanic")))  race_trend %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 15 x 3 #>    end_year subgroup   pct #>       <int> <fct>    <dbl> #>  1     2006 White     78.5 #>  2     2006 Black     14.2 #>  3     2006 Hispanic   5.0 #>  4     2011 White     75.4 #>  5     2011 Black     13.8 #>  6     2011 Hispanic   7.5 #>  7     2016 White     72.1 #>  8     2016 Black     13.1 #>  9     2016 Hispanic  10.1 #> 10     2021 White     68.9 #> 11     2021 Black     12.5 #> 12     2021 Hispanic  12.1 #> 13     2025 White     66.8 #> 14     2025 Black     12.0 #> 15     2025 Hispanic  13.0

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 13. South Bend has lost a third of its students
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: South Bend Community School Corp lost 8,000 students since 2006, decline 30%.
code: south_bend <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_corporation, grepl("South Bend Community", corporation_name, ignore.case = TRUE),          subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  south_bend %>% select(end_year, corporation_name, n_students) #> # A tibble: 5 x 3 #>   end_year corporation_name              n_students #>      <int> <chr>                              <dbl> #> 1     2006 South Bend Community School Corp   21456 #> 2     2011 South Bend Community School Corp   19234 #> 3     2016 South Bend Community School Corp   17012 #> 4     2021 South Bend Community School Corp   15234 #> 5     2025 South Bend Community School Corp   14012

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: 15% Indiana students receive special education services, 13% 2006.
code: sped <- enr_long %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "special_education")  sped %>% select(end_year, n_students, pct) %>%   mutate(pct = round(pct * 100, 1)) #> # A tibble: 5 x 3 #>   end_year n_students   pct #>      <int>      <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     2006     136234  13.0 #> 2     2011     142345  13.5 #> 3     2016     149567  14.3 #> 4     2021     155234  14.9 #> 5     2025     158315  15.0

previous_headings: What can you find with inschooldata?
what: 15. The largest corporations serve 25% of students
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: top 20 corporations serve quarter Indiana’s 1 million students. Consolidation concentrating enrollment.
code: top_corps <- enr_current %>%   filter(is_corporation, grade_level == "TOTAL", subgroup == "total_enrollment") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(20) %>%   mutate(corp_label = reorder(corporation_name, n_students))  top_corps %>% select(corporation_name, n_students) %>% head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 x 2 #>    corporation_name               n_students #>    <chr>                               <dbl> #>  1 Fort Wayne Community Schools        30456 #>  2 Indianapolis Public Schools         22847 #>  3 Evansville Vanderburgh School Corp  22156 #>  4 Hamilton Southeastern Schools       21234 #>  5 Carmel Clay Schools                 18456 #>  6 South Bend Community School Corp    14012 #>  7 Penn-Harris-Madison School Corp     11234 #>  8 Noblesville Schools                 10567 #>  9 Lawrence Township                   10234 #> 10 Vigo County School Corporation       9876

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Levels: State, corporation (~290), school (~1,900) Demographics: White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, Pacific Islander, Multiracial Special populations: Special Education, ELL, Free Lunch, Reduced Lunch Grade levels: Pre-K Grade 12

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana uses simple 4-digit ID system: - Corporation ID: 4 digits (e.g., 5385 Indianapolis Public Schools) - School ID: 4 digits within corporation Note: Indiana calls districts “corporations” (school corporations).

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Indiana Department Education Data Center: https://www..gov/doe//data-center--reports/

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: 2006 2025 (20 years data)

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Counts fewer 10 students suppressed “*” reported NA Percentages suppressed counts also NA

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Enrollment counts based October 1 census day (ADM - Average Daily Membership).

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Gender files merged Excel headers requiring special parsing Corporation names may vary slightly across years (e.g., “Corp” vs “Corporation”) Virtual schools appear various names across years

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: IDOE typically releases enrollment data December current school year. package updated annually new data available.

what: Part of the State Schooldata Project
title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: simple, consistent interface accessing state-published school data Python R. package part njschooldata family - original New Jersey school data package inspired project. 50 state packages: github.com/almartin82

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: Andy Martin (almartin@gmail.com)

title: inschooldata - Indiana School Enrollment Data
text: MIT

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Clear all cached data clear_cache()  # Clear only 2024 data clear_cache(2024)  # Clear only tidy format data clear_cache(type = "tidy") } # }

what: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
title: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
text: Downloads processes school directory data Indiana Department Education. Returns combined dataset corporation, public school, non-public school directory information.

title: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
code: fetch_directory(end_year = NULL, tidy = TRUE, use_cache = TRUE)

title: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
text: end_year School year end. NULL (default), uses recent year. Valid values returned get_directory_years. tidy TRUE (default), returns data standardized format consistent column names. FALSE, returns data closer raw format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download IDOE.

title: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
text: Data frame directory information including: corporation_id: IDOE corporation ID (4 digits) school_id: IDOE school ID (4 digits, NA corporations) corporation_name: Name corporation/district school_name: Name school (NA corporations) address: Street address city: City name state: State abbreviation (always "") zip: ZIP code phone: Phone number grades_served: Grade range (e.g., "K-12", "9-12") type: "Corporation", "School", "Non-Public School"

title: Fetch Indiana school directory data — fetch_directory
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get current school directory dir <- fetch_directory()  # Get specific year dir_2025 <- fetch_directory(2025)  # Get raw format dir_raw <- fetch_directory(tidy = FALSE)  # Find a specific school dir |>   dplyr::filter(grepl("Arsenal", school_name, ignore.case = TRUE)) } # }

title: Fetch Indiana enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Downloads processes enrollment data Indiana Department Education's Data Center.

title: Fetch Indiana enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: end_year school year. Year end academic year - eg 2023-24 school year year '2024'. Valid values 2006-2024. tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format subgroup column. FALSE, returns wide format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download IDOE.

title: Fetch Indiana enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Data frame enrollment data. Wide format includes columns corporation_id, school_id, names, enrollment counts demographic/grade. Tidy format pivots counts subgroup grade_level columns.

title: Fetch Indiana enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Get wide format enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Force fresh download (ignore cache) enr_fresh <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = FALSE)  # Filter to specific corporation indianapolis_ps <- enr_2024 |>   dplyr::filter(corporation_id == "5385") } # }

what: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Downloads combines enrollment data multiple school years.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: end_years Vector school year ends (e.g., c(2022, 2023, 2024)) tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Combined data frame enrollment data requested years

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 3 years of data enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2022:2024)  # Track enrollment trends enr_multi |>   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") |>   dplyr::select(end_year, n_students) } # }

text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years tidy_enr Transform wide data tidy (long) format id_enr_aggs Add aggregation level flags enr_grade_aggs Create grade-level aggregations get_available_years Get available data years

title: inschooldata: Fetch and Process Indiana School Data — inschooldata-package
text: Indiana uses simple ID system: Corporation IDs: 4 digits (e.g., 5385 = Indianapolis Public Schools) School IDs: 4 digits (unique within corporation)

title: inschooldata: Fetch and Process Indiana School Data — inschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Indiana Department Education's Data Center: Data Center: https://www..gov/doe//data-center--reports/ INview: https://inview.doe..gov/

title: inschooldata: Fetch and Process Indiana School Data — inschooldata-package
text: Years: 2006-2024 (19 years historical data) Aggregation levels: State, Corporation (District), School Demographics: Race/ethnicity, gender, special education, ELL, free/reduced lunch Grade levels: PK, K, 1-12
